text: I have a question for you do you know how you actually make money in trading I asked this because I had a conversation in my Discord a couple days ago that really reminded me that a lot of people have kind of these different Notions about where and how they make money but they really don't understand at a base level the function that leads to making money and I'm going to walk you through three ways to actually make money in the stock market and no one of the ways to make money isn't day trading you can lose money day trading so what I hope to do is to get us to a better understanding of the actual functions that lead to making money so that you can spend more time focusing on developing those functions so that you can make more money what's up everybody Eric here welcome back to all the outliers and a shout out to the patreon family you guys make content like this possible so that my video editor can make these fun for all of us to watch and uh yeah so you guys are paying him so he thanks you let's take a look at what I'm talking about here I want to start with some level setting this was from the Discord now I blanked out the dude's name because this isn't meant to drag anybody this is literally meant to have a conversation because my guess is the

options and not make money you can day trade Futures and not make money these the specific Futures options stocks those are just products Buy and Hold is a strategy swing trading is a type of strategy day trading is a type of strategy none of those inherently lead to making money so again my hope is to get people to a closer understanding of what functions actually make money because in this example if I were to ask this Trader how do you make more money they might say well I need to day trade Futures more that probably actually is the worst thing they could possibly do the worst IDE I ever heard but they view that as a way to make money so let's get to the heart and soul of what's Happening Here I asked what are the actual functions that lead to making money and they responded with trading buy and sell which is kind of reiterating this slightly different and then I kind of pointed out what I just pointed out to you that none of these essentially inherently lead to making money another thing I saw in the option subreddit was this I've built together this option strategy it seems to guarantee a profit let's just just you know completely pretend that guarantee at least was spelled correct in the context of talking about something that automatically makes a profit in options trading now to be clear if he was Trading long box

important to call out because you can be good at determining Direction in a bunch of different capacities you could have a very high win rate but a low average win and moderate losses that in agur aggregate is positively expecting you could have another scenario where you actually have a very low win R you could be right 25 of the time but if your winning trades are big enough you can still make money so this is why I believe in this scenario there's two things that we really need to focus on is getting good at determining Direction and some capacity but then also intertwining managing money effectively being able to follow winning trades if that's your style being able to capture a certain win amount if you're trying to hit a higher win rate but directional trading is a really common one the next one we have is risk assumption so this is kind of also known as structural Alpha and this is where we assume other people's risk this is the very commonly cited risk Premia in options trading now there are other ways you can assume risk for people there are other kinds of structural Alpha that just risk premiums is one of them and this is essentially the force where if we take a look at spy here we go 29 days out just picking an expiration and we look at the 443 puts that's oh I'm sorry let's look at the 445s

structural Alpha that just risk premiums is one of them and this is essentially the force where if we take a look at spy here we go 29 days out just picking an expiration and we look at the 443 puts that's oh I'm sorry let's look at the 445s the 445s are a 34 Delta and those are trading for 384 for the 445s 34 Delta now if we look at the corresponding 34 Delta call same expiration those are only trading for 297 so why is there an extra dollar essentially on these puts that's putc that is structural Alpha this is showing us that the theoretical understanding of options pricing is not what happens in the markets because people are willingly overpaying for puts and that's for a bunch of different reasons this is why things like this do exist because a lot of the times when we talk about the stock market we talk about it in the context of a theoretical vacuum where everything's perfect everybody's a rational actor but we know markets are not rational and we also know that there are a lot of players that have a bunch of rules they have to follow if you're a pension fund manager and you want to keep your job next quarter you can't have big draw Downs so they would rather overpay for downside protection so that they can keep their job and sacrifice some profit potential knowing that they're inefficiently buying that protection

be a market maker turns on their quote machine and literally it has the wrong price that is insanely improbable it's not frequent at all and your capacity one to spot it fast enough to then Trade It is essentially zero it's not impossible entirely but it's so insanely unlikely there are literally alos that are looking for stuff like that and if you think about really these kind of two styles of trading assuming risk or looking for structural alpha or looking for inefficiencies you're kind of providing a service in all of these circumstances because here the service you're providing is taking somebody else's risk here let's say if you could catch one of these mispricings you are then normalizing prices to what they should be in a set Market Marketplace then there's things like cross exchange Arbitrage this is where you find something on one exchange that might be trading expensive and you sell it and you buy it on another exchange where it's trading cheaply here you are normalizing prices but you are also providing liquidity that's another service you're providing value dissonance is interesting because this is kind of when we can clearly see and have a system to assess when a move is overdone and there's a break from the current price of something and whatever you perceive the value to be because again going back to periods of mania like GameStop where that was a short squeeze that turned into a bit of

have a system to assess when a move is overdone and there's a break from the current price of something and whatever you perceive the value to be because again going back to periods of mania like GameStop where that was a short squeeze that turned into a bit of a pump and dump where people are still waiting for the mother of all squeezes to come up and there are different forces that happen there but during that squeeze there's value dissonance that starts to occur where nobody looks at that and says GameStop is worth this nobody thinks that but because of structural forces in the markets and artificial manipulation we saw this giant move in price and you could have either rode it to the upside or taking the short to the downside when it eventually did collapse but you can find ways to look for Value that's just completely out of whack and to place a trade on it there's also things like peed and no this is not what you do with your boyfriend in the bathtub on the weekends this is positive earnings announcement drift this is a really well-studied Force where after an earnings release if something has a really great release and a giant beat to the upside there's certain parameters that have to be met and there are studies that you can find on ssrn on this thing that over the next quarter they tend to go on and have outsized

earnings release if something has a really great release and a giant beat to the upside there's certain parameters that have to be met and there are studies that you can find on ssrn on this thing that over the next quarter they tend to go on and have outsized returns that's because the market is not efficient enough to price in that new information quickly enough and it takes time for it to be digested that's exactly what leads to this that is a potential way for you to make money as a Trader the point here is every single one of these things is tied to a way discreetly to make money if you are directionally correct if you are able to price and take risk for other people providing a service or if you can find different types of these efficiencies inefficiencies sorry there's all different kinds of these and then if you have any questions on how do you build a strategy around this well I have a video that I'll throw in the link in the notes Below on this exact thing that really goes into building an option strategy in depth however this is the general flow that you're going to take so let's say that your profit mechanism is being directionally correct your hypothesis is one of two things one of three things you could pick whatever your hypothesis is but let's just say your hypothesis is that you can use technical analysis
